comments.text:
I have 9070XT already for 2 months and I am selling it and buying 5070 Ti.

You ask me why when AMD has really a good piece of hardware? 

Yes, they have, they always had, but that's not all. Today laggy games on Unreal have massive delay and only thing that can make it playable for me is nvidia reflex, also AMD GPUs generally have higher lag even in older games where I don't have any lag with nvidia GPU.

I know that the vast majority of people don't feel these lags or they just don't care, so buy AMD if you don't care about this, but it's important for me.
With reflex on, even 25 FPS un UE5 game is kind of playable. Don't beleive? Try it, it was never about how many FPS you have, it's mainly about latency and I don't mean frametime, I mean total latency of whole computer that can be even 200 ms with lower FPS in UE5 game and that's a lot, it's not playable for me even when it shows 60+ FPS. Ofcourse nvidia marketing is very much about frame generation that causes another lag, but you can turn frame generation off, it's not mandatory.

Second thing is that implementation of FSR is not good in all games, while DLSS looked pretty good already in DLSS 2 version and there are still games that support only DLSS, for example Crysis Remastered and you think you can play native? No, you can't in today pixelated games that rely on TAA or upscaling to stabilize image.



I know this is not literally fault of AMD, but it's reality, I want to play games, not constantly complain about some lags or game not supporting FSR, not even talking about games with forced ray tracing, I know, AMD did a massive step forward in RT performance with 9000 series, but it's still slower than nvidia and more and more games (unfortunatelly) have forced ray tracing.
I am not hating AMD, I am just saying some facts, I am building computers for more than 20 years and I have my experiences that says that AMD people can create such hype about their products that you will fall into it, then you buy it and realize it's not that great as they told you, it's happening all the time again and again.

I just wish we could return 10 years to the history with no bullshit supported only one specific brand of GPUs. Yes, there was already PhysX, but that was nevery widly used and it survived only few years.
When there was no upscaling, RT and such bullshits and AMD had good old stable and reliable catalyst drivers, I would say "yes, definitely buy AMD, there is nothing wrong with that" but today? Think carefully about that and always have in your mind that AMD fanatics are really really loud, much louder than nvidia marketing, so they very succesfully created an image that nvidia is not working crap with black screens, while in reality, it's a problem of few people and they totally ignore AMD's driver issues, they call you a liar and nvidia fan boy when you want to talk about it.

Buy whatever you want, but things are not that black and white as someone told you, I don't trust anyone, only my experiences.
It's the same with CPUs, are AMD CPUs good? Yes, definitely. Are AMD CPUs the best technology on Earth and are totally superior compared to "terrible, outdated, hot" intel? Definitely not.

I checked the price for the 7900 XT and 7900XTX prices and they mirror RX 9070 XT and 570 TI. RX  7900 XT is around 875 USD and RX 7900 XTX is 1175 USD(converted to usd from local currency), at which point I think 7900 XT is probably the best option. Atleast it is according to me.

comments.text:
Lesson learned:
Set an appealing MSRP (even if "fake MSRP") -> get good reviews -> sell lots of product -> price goes up due to demand

Good reviews -> big hype and inflated prices
Negative reviews -> ignored by consumers and price cuts

So negative reviews (if it's due to poor value) are good for savvy customers who know how to wait for good deals 🤔
(Basically, the best value option is almost always the less hyped option, and vice versa - you're paying the popularity tax)

comments.text:
DLSS vs FSR makes comparing hard...
I have an RTX4070. In Oblivion Remastered, I ended up finally using FRAME GENERATION which I normally won't use but I was forced to massively lower quality or use Frame Gen to hit around 80FPS+ average minimums outdoors (which I care about due to PERSISTANCE BLUR on the monitor). It works pretty well. The combination of AI upscaling plus Frame Gen means the visual quality can take a huge hit if it's not done well. NVidia's doing a pretty good job. I can't speak to AMD, but I doubt it's as good which makes comparing difficult. So even if AMD gives you a big raster uplift if you try to normalize for overal visual quality at, say, 80FPS then NVidia probably wins.
I'm rooting for AMD, so hopefully their FSR can continue to improve and get easily pushed to older titles.

comments.text:
Steve, thanks for the great content as usual. And pretty timely in my case.

I'm in the US. I bought a 9070 xt from my local microcenter a few days ago for $800. I know the 5070 ti performs better for a similar price. But it's got that 12V high power connector. From what I saw the 9070 xt (or arguably the 7900 xtx) was the best card I could get with standard 8 pin power. I'm building workstations. My machines run for months before I'm forced to reboot for updates. I cannot supervise them 24/7 to ensure they don't catch fire. I know the probability is low. That's not good enough. If NVIDIA sold a TV that could burn down your house or office the regulatory agencies would crawl up their backside and setup camp. I don't know why graphics cards are different. Adding sense resistors per wire seems like a cheap and easy fix. NVIDIA has been flailing about on this connector for years now. I don't get it.

I know the 9070 xt is currently overpriced compared to MSRP (although this could be considered anchoring bias). But I remember prices being closer to $1K not too long ago. I wasn't enthused with $800 but I was ok with it. For others waiting for a cheaper price, I wish you the best of luck.

To be clear, I would have stayed with NVIDIA if I could have. The issue wasn't price (within reason), it was that damn connector.
comments.author: @darkwzrd00

comments.text: The standard 8 pin was part of my decision to go for a 9070 as well. IMO it is just a bad connector and needs to be withdrawn, I would never use anything so failure prone in a professional context so why accept it in a domestic one.

comments.text:
Huh?  Dunno where you're seeing 5070Ti's available at MRSP!  BestBuy has nothing in-stock or for backorder and Canada Computers have about ten(!) in-stores (in five of about 25 stores) in all of Ontario (16 million people), and none for order!  

Also, you're not going to find a 9070XT for even $100 more that a 5070 (the 5070 FE is $799 at BestBuy and can be backordered or just buy the Asus Prime), MSRP 9070 XT's (at $860) never existed and around $950 has always been the baseline starting price (I got a Gigabyte "OC" version for $949 on release day), so a 9070 XT is at a minimum $150 more than a 5070 .  If you could get the Asus Prime 5070Ti at the listed $1089 BestBuy price, that would only put it about $100 more than a 9070XT and that would be a no-brainer...

Assuming you can drive to stores (or maybe order, where possible), here are the REAL lowest prices:

- 5070 (FE, if you like one!): $799
- 5070Ti - $1089
- 9070XT - $949

So, NO, a 9070XT is not "200-250 cheaper" than a 5070Ti!  

P.S. For those curious, Canadian prices on nVidia cards tend to be very close to the announced US MSRP prices, usually within a few dollars of the basic exchange rate.  Very "fair", no gouging in any real way, buuut, you have to be patient for them to show-up!

comments.text:
Na I'm sorry man I dont agree with the value numbers in America. Ive been watching Amazon and Newegg mostly.

 You have to take into effect what our Tariffs are doing to pricing, rn pretty sure we have 10% fron Taiwan and Vietnam. So now look at what Manufacturers make and from what country. Almost all Brands Available in the USA are from China except Gigabyte and I think Asrock.
 Ive had a chance to pick up the Gaming and Gaming-OC cards from newegg, 5x for OC and 2-3x for the Gaming. $729 for the OC and $669 for the Gaming. Not to mention I just watched the OC card go in a Bundle with a Gigabyte ATX Gaming Mobo for $909 be available for 3 Days Tbh I almost bought one myself but I dont really need a GPU rn ( it's Okay I like to watch 👍).
 Personally I think with a 10-20% Tariff and being an AIB Custom card not a bog standard Design $669-729 for a 9070XT is perfectly reasonable to reflect from a $600 msrp OEM Design or AMD incentivized  Colab.

 These Prices only get worse with any other Brand simply because of supply chain Tariffs, and lets be honest with what China has going on rn... probably is effecting how fast anything is being made and exported from China. Couple with supply and demand well you see the availability 🤷‍♂️ do what u can.

 Me, I'll wait for a convenient time and snag a Gigabyte Gaming-OC 9070xt. For me a 5070 cant hold a candle to a 9070xt in what "I want". legacy/raster, FSR4 is compatible going forward for newer games + Optiscaler injection into DLSS, abit of Vram 16gb, Linux and SteamOS support and afew applications to play with in rendering and AI... and I happen to think AMDs HEVC encoder Specifically in Handbrake to be just fine for Transcoding.

 Sorry Imo I dont think a blanket 20% delta is a good representation of 5070 vs 9070xt... RT, Scalers, Vram, Drivers Features, Raster/Legacy Gaming, Linux/SteamOS support, WIN Productivity Apps.

Idk what to even say about the 5070 pricing but I know I havnt noticed any cheap 5070 cards more like pushing $700 and for that, na almost equal pricing to 9070XT Gigabyte not even a contest.

comments.text:
It would be really nice if you guys included frame times in your benchmarks because raw FPS only gets you so far. In fact, higher frame rates don't always mean a smoother experience, and after about 100 FPS, the effect higher frames have on the game becomes negligible since increasing frame rates just have diminishing returns. At least outside of better input latency.

If you put more of a focus on frame times, you'd have a much more detailed picture of how the game is actually playing on specific hardware. If the 5070 TI, for example, is getting something like 150 FPS but frame times are consistently unstable, then it's going to feel horrible to play. However, we won't know that just by going off of a graph with frame rate comparisons.

Also, the 9070 XT is of way better value than the 5070 TI here in Aus. There's like a difference of $200 to $250 AUD between the cheaper models of each card, and if you take what I said about high frame rates being less valuable then smooth frame times, then it makes your cost per frame thing seem pointless and even missrepresentative of a cards actual value.

But now I'm aware that a Red Devil white model exists... which has been permanently out of stock at Micro Center. And the nearest Micro center to me is about two days of road trip in each direction.
I don't care who or what is at fault; I'm just sick and fed up with being told the card exists and how much of an upgrade it should be, and then repeatedly being told I can't buy one even if it's in stock. I've seriously had enough of this situation.

@benjaminoechsli1941  did these nvidia card prices come down rapidly (meaning recently) or has this slowly been going down for weeks? I stopped following prices once i got a card.
the reason i'm asking is: everyone that's shopping for a card has a threshold at which a certain price difference between amd and nivida would change his choice. And while I don't agree on HWUB's 20% (meaning people preferring to pay 19% more for the same perf to get an nivida), I'm astonished people would pay more for AMD than for nivida.
So I'm wondering if this price decrease for nvidia happened so recently and spontaniously that buyers and hence AMD prices simply haven't reacted to it yet.

I bougt an RX 9070 XT, like maybe 2 months ago, in the EU. But e.g. my threshold would have been 50€. i would have gone RTX 5070 TI if it had cost within max 50€ (and good supply at that price to cover exchange in case of missing ROPs). Because while that was in the period of nvidia pushing broken driver fix after broken driver fix, realistically they would fix drivers eventually.

From CCL in the UK, these are the cheapest of each model:
5070 - Palit GeForce RTX 5070 Infinity 3 12GB GPU, £515 (one of four models under £550, its OC brother being a penny under £550)
5070 Ti - Palit GeForce RTX 5070 Ti GamingPro V1 16GB GPU, £770 (its OC brother being the only other 5070 Ti below £800 (if only by a single pence))
9070 - Gigabyte Radeon RX 9070 GAMING OC 16GB GDDR6, £578; as there are only three models I may as well list them all - XFX Radeon RX 9070 Swift OC 16GB GDDR6, £610 and ASUS Radeon RX 9070 TUF OC 16GB GDDR6, £690
9070 XT - ASUS Radeon RX 9070 XT TUF OC 16GB GDDR6 Graphics Card, £667 (oddly, £23 cheaper than the non-XT model, and one of four models under £700)

As such, for this single retailer in the UK, the cheapest 9070 XT is 30% pricier than the cheapest 5070, and 13% cheaper than the cheapest 5070 XT, and though both of the NVIDIA models are running at stock clocks, the price increase for the mildly-overclocked OC models definitely harms their value somewhat - an additional £35 for the non-Ti and £30 for the Ti, which would change the comparison so that the 9070 XT was 21% pricier than the 5070 and 17% cheaper than the Ti (assuming my maths is correct).

comments.text:
I got the Sapphire Nitro+ 9070 XT for £689, about £100 cheaper than the cheapest 5070 Ti's available as of a week ago in the UK. Best AIB version of 9070 XT vs cheapest (but still £100 more expensive) AIB model of the 5070 Ti. Made the choice quite easy for me. Still feels a bit underwhelming, given that I'm upgrading from an RX 6800 XT. It's about 30-40% faster than the 6800 XT outside of RT workloads, the only reason I upgraded was because my relative wanted to buy my 6800 XT for £300, making my upgrade cost a much more palatable £389.

Bear in mind the £689 price of the Nitro+ I got is its MSRP price and that's supposed to be a premium board partner model, which I was lucky to get as just about every other premium AIB model is selling for at least £50 more, and every basic cheap AIB model is the same price at around £680 minimum. You can get a 5070 non-Ti for around £520, making it around 25% cheaper, whilst being 17-21% slower according to these evidently thorough benchmarks. 

At £517 which is the cheapest price I've seen, the 5070 is actually the best value out of the lot in the UK but it wouldn't have been much of an upgrade from my 6800 XT anyway, so for me, personally, the value in the £389 I spent is in the 30-40% better performance (and far better RT, and FSR4), versus what would have been just 10-20% better performance outside of RT if I had gotten the 5070.  5070 Ti is easily the worst value of the lot, and the 9070 XT comes in at only a bit better value than the 5070 Ti.

Value comparisons only really work if you assume ideal circumstances, market stability and so on, assuming the buyer isn't selling off an old GPU to subsidise the upgrade, and assuming they don't have an existing gaming PC at all which would necessarily make the performance increase more valuable per % increase. Like in my case, paying £220 for a 10-20% performance uplift sounds a lot less enticing and worthwhile than £389 for 30-40%. Won't apply to everyone of course but for those that it does, consider that subsidising your upgrade by selling off your old GPU can change the value outlook and make the cost sting a lot less. That being said, the real motivation for me personally to upgrade was games like Oblivion Remastered, Doom The Dark Ages and Indiana Jones using always-on RT, which makes a bigger difference than usual between the 9070 XT and 6800 XT. If it weren't for games leaving behind the weak RT performance of the 6800 XT, and it struggling to keep up with those few games, even a subsidised £389 for 30-40% (non-RT) more performance wouldn't have been an appealing value for me. It's the wider adoption of RT that makes my upgrade sting a lot less, because in those games it can be from 75 to 110% faster. In short, value comparisons aren't static, the market fluctuates erratically from one week to the next, any and all value conclusions can and probably will be irrelevant in short notice, therefore the most important thing is to be informed of the differences between GPU models and do your due diligence to inform yourself of where the value REALLY lies for YOUR particular circumstances, whether you're buying fresh as a newbie, selling off your old PC, or upgrading and keeping your old GPU as a backup. Many things like this can drastically change the perceived value of a particular component. 

Also as a sidenote FSR4 in Oblivion Remastered is legitimately a game changer, the difference is indescribable. Easily the worst FSR3 implementation I have ever seen, but FSR4 cleans it up so much it's almost a miracle.
What I said
comments.author: @senilestix

I was totally impressed with the Radeon’s quality compared to MSI’s 5070ti. Performance wise…….alot depends on your CPU pairing……….and the x3d CPU’s are just monsters. Still……I have issues with the build quality of the Nvidia card. At $1500 Canadian (taxes in)……….I question the longevity of the MSI card based on its’ build quality and the XFX 9070xt was just very much more impressive visually. I’m not disagreeing with “Hardware Unboxed”……….just offering an alternate perspective on value for your money.  Of the two cards, I choose the XFX 9070xt every single day. comments.text:
I ask again. Is it possible to get a benchmark, even just for 3-4 games, most, comparing energy efficiency for a few cards of current and previous generations at capped settings and fps?
For example - I am using a RX 6800 XT card. I play Cyberpunk. 
I managed to adjust my GPU to give me 144 fps with FSR 3 at just using 115 W of power. 
I only want to upgrade to a new card if I can get 144 fps with the same settings and save more power. So I would need to know this: If I bought a 9070 to replace my 6800 XT, how much power would the card draw to deliver the same performance? 

I cannot see this out of any reviewers data. It is impossible to tell when the performance to watts ratio drops into the inefficient bracket. (maybe the last 10% of performance require 35% of the total power draw).
I really do not know why no one really covers this. Why would I care about 300+ fps when I have a 144 Hz/ 165 Hz monitor? The only upgrade for me is: at 144 Hz / fps you save this much energy when you upgrade to this newer generation.

comments.text:
The fun thing is, every now and then (2.5 weeks it seems) the price of all amd cards drops by 30-50€ (more if it had a price spike), then it goes up by an almost similar amount to repeat the process. This suggests: The Amd cards are still highly sought after. And while we can complain, the 900€ bracket (belgium) is finally extinct, 870 is now max for nitro + (perhaps it's popular design makes it slower to go down in price). But the Red devil/Hellhound has been 770-790€ lately (with the Sapphire pulse at 760€ i'd say the hellhound is pretty attractive). Not perpect yet. I'm waiting :D If what you say is true the sales will fall, if the sales fall... The 700€ bracket will be easely reached, easely cause all 7900xt are over a year now in the 700-760€ bracket and that card was more expensive to make.

Nvidia is cheaper, but only on VERY VERY VERY few mspr cards like gigabyte windforce and I think msi ventus, and some pny model. All other cards are 150-250€ more expensive then 9070xt, so if you want a high end card: The amd ones (Red devil at790 €) is more interesting then Asus tuf Nvidia 5070 ti at 1049€. It is not all black and White steve.

That being said 5070 ti is sometimes tempting, but then i think how bad this generation is, that 880€ should be 20gb of ram, 5070 ti isnt noteworthy faster (the lows are even better on amd card). And 5070... 12gb kills it, at 600€ i will never buy it, 7800xt at 500€ (now a bit higher due to lack of stock) has 16gb ram, NO thanks 5070! And i think lot of people think the same (you are a bit to blame Steve :D So that in essence lowers the 5070 demand and ups the 9070 xt, plus prices are moving down, no matter how much to high that always gives hope. The 5070 ti 'msrp' models (the few ones that are much cheaper sitting around 879€, wich is exactly msrp) will never move lower, i know this as a fact becuase 4070 ti (super), never dropped below it's 920€ msrp, few models did, and the moment of even remotely a minor shortage, they pumped 1050€ (the high end cards always being 1080-1150€)

So yeah is Nvidia that much better value? I kinda disagree, sure the msrp models made a strong leap in price, kudo's for that (amd should do that too btw), but anything else? Anything high end? 5080 value? Forget about it.

And lets not forget 5070, fps may be lower, but it has 16gb of ram, and while msrp to high, we all know it will drop in price (or being held for china market to keep it high in rest of world) but we will see how it turns out, is a bit of a 'GRE' model (7900 gre sort off).

comments.text:
​ @nk-dw2hm  you can delete all textures from the games objects and still used up all your VRAM))
It's used for a lot more than just textures for objects. Llike pages for clusters of objects, baked or virtual textures(like shadows/illumination), simulations data, streaming whatever need to be streamed, a lot of maps(like weight/height for landscape etc), distance fields, probes, for rendering of the scene which in deferred and can be done like 20 times before being composited into 1 frame, etc.
And majority of that is scaling from resolution.

yea, 12gb is not much, i'd get 16gb minimum, 100%, but 12 is ok'ish for a few years. id rather take 5070 with 12 than 5060ti with 16.(both are bad tho)

comments.text:
@Mcnooblet  
The NVidia driver issues are well known.
I personally was affected. My system had been rock solid for years. Then it started crashing. I watched Gamers Nexus and found the workaround (rolling back my driver). Then a NEW driver came out claiming to fix THOSE problems and caused me a problem as the GPU TEMPERATURE SENSOR information wasn't being reported through the NVidia driver. So my fans (controlled through the mobo as I modded them) were only spinning at 350RPM as my system thought the temp was 27degC. So my GPU was overheating then throttling down to protect itself so my FPS plummeted until I figured that out.
And I have an RTX4070. The RTX50 crowd are dealing with a tonne of issues, which seem to be worse if you have more than one monitor.

I have seen also some 9070 xt models lowering prices here. Still overpriced imo and not msrp, but to me it seems with every new consumer pc gpu generation people get more anxious. Waiting for prices settling down and for good deals becoming the thing of the past. And the most "fun" part is we get less of if any hw performance boost every new generation added with higly inflated price tags and at best misleading marketing. Ever increasing part of what you pay for is now just air. Very expensive air. 

Rather we get now basically only brand and generation exclusive software boosts to performance. Essentially AI boost, not hardware boost. And pc gamers embrace that trend with open arms. I think its disgusting and very short sighted. Not that im suprised of it per se. I do hope i can get more into my other hobbies than gaming in near future. Its just that i would have to invest so much more in to them to be way more occupied in those hobbies in my free time. But with current trends of rising costs and requirements of gaming it wont feel as bad. I guess in the end its a positive.

comments.text:
This is obviously one of the limitations of these sorts of comparisons. Because finding a card can be very luck and location dependant, it's hard to say what the true going price is without spending a lot of time looking. To that extent, I think using Newegg pricing, which generally tends to be more stable, but more expensive, than the low quantities available online or in-person from other retailers, is reasonable.

Like you said, you've been able to get the 9070XT for around $960 CAD over the last month or so provided you're lucky to catch one online, or happen to live near a store, and over the last few weeks the 5070 Ti has been available at the $1090 CAD MRSP multiple times to order online for as long as 12-24 hours.

I haven't watched the 5070 pricing as closely, but currently there's a fair amount of availability from $760-800 CAD.

Overall, it 's really unfortunate that AMD hasn't been able to supply 9070XTs closer to the ~$850 CAD MSRP, because I think it's a lot more compelling than Nvidia's offerings when it is priced correctly. Currently it's tough to say whether it's worth it to grab a 9070XT when the 5070 Ti for ~$130 more offers far better features with much wider support.

comments.text:
That seems like a disingenious misrepresentation or at the absolute minimum is so HIGHLY region specific that making this assertion as a blanket statement would be false.
Here in Germany, the 9070 XT has always been the cheaper the card and at times for quite a considerable margin (like 250-300€ price difference) and still is considerably cheaper than the 5070 Ti, more importantly it is still cheaper in relative performance. For the longest time, the Nvidia GPU pricing was simply hilarious. When the 9070 XT launched in Hermany, you could (if you were faster than then buy bots or used one yourself) you could get a 9070 XT for 689€ whereas the 5070 Ti still hovered at the 1000€ price mark.

To me it seems less that AMD tried to fool people into thinking its cards are better value than they are and more the case that Nvidia has at long last managed to deliver some inventory and between higher supply and less demand for overpriced cards (the 5090 sold out at basically any price, but the 5070 Ti not so) plus a credible competing product meant prices have finally come down to the point that it's somewhat of a competition.

comments.text:
@Steamrick  That's an optimistic idea, but I'm afraid that it won't happen. Partially this is because people keeps paying these prices no matter how much you think it's insane, and partly because the parts actually cost more to make now than they did a decade ago. Manufacturing prices has gone up, and both AMD and nVidia has to pay for the development costs. Sure you don't think it's all that amazing, but the cost is still high. Then there's driver development, and we all want them to continue that. Even the borked nVidia drivers costs a lot of money to develop, and AMD has finally got rid of the old driver problems and that's not something that happens because they pay the driver team less money.
In fact just as we see prices go up the people making these products are facing the same situation and they, like us, want a higher wage to compensate, and that money is coming from the same company that makes the products we are complaining about.
It's not a simple equation but we've seen it before. Higher prices drive wages which drive prices higher again...

So I don't think that just asking people to stop buying graphics cards will really help change the situation. If anything it might slow down the development of new and more demanding games for a while. Developers are dependent on the available market space being able and willing to spend money on their products. If the market slows down they will concentrate on making games that will run on the hardware that most people are willing to pay for. This would mean we would be seeing less spectacular games and get more of the same type of games we've spent the last decade playing. This might not be the worst result, but at the same time I want to see the new shiny!
